title: Salesman's Sample

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of silk, plain weave with supplementary patterning warps, supplementary patterning wefts, and two color supplementary pile warps forming cut solid velvet; appliquéd with linen, knotted netting; embroidered with silk floss and yarns in outline, satin, padded satin, single satin and stem stitches; couching and french knots.

description: The survival of thousands of small embroidery samples for men’s suits and coats indicates the scope and scale of the Lyonnaise embroidery workshops specializing in men’s fashion. Patterns were marketed both domestically in France and throughout Europe. Indeed, French taste so dominated European fashion that when foreign diplomats came to France, they felt obliged to buy the latest styles in Paris before they appeared at court.
medium_display: Silk, plain weave with supplementary patterning warps, supplementary patterning wefts, and two color supplementary pile warps forming cut solid velvet; appliquéd with linen, knotted netting; embroidered with silk floss and yarns in outline, satin, padded satin, single satin and stem stitches; couching and French knots
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Chauncey B. Borland
publication_history:
Mayer, Christa Charlotte. Masterpieces of Western Textiles. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1969. pl. 124, p. 157.

Selected Works of 18th century French Art in the Collections of the Art Institute of Chicago. Chicago, 1976. No. 334, p. 211. (.ill)

Waterman, V. Ann. Surface Pattern Design: A Handbook of How to Create Decorative and Repeat Patterns for Designers and students. New York: Hastings House Publishers, 1984. p. 86.
exhibition_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, Masterpieces of Western Textiles, Jan. 25–Mar. 2, 1969.

Art Institute of Chicago, Selected Works of Eighteenth Century French Art in the Collections of The Art Institute of Chicago, Jan. 24–Mar. 28, 1976.

provenance_text: Mrs. Chauncy B. Borland [Belle Borland, born McCullough], Chicago, IL, by Oct. 1956 [Incoming permanent receipt RX1992 dated Oct. 1, 1956 in curatorial object file, Textiles Department]; given to the Art Institute of Chicago.
